title: Nouns: countable and uncountable
description: Practice identifying and using countable and uncountable nouns correctly in sentences.

questions.question: Which noun is uncountable?
questions.explanation: 'Rice' is uncountable; you cannot say 'a rice' or 'rices'.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: 'Bread' is uncountable, so use 'some bread'.

questions.question: Complete: There isn't _____ coffee in the cup.

content.sentence: There isn't _____ coffee in the cup.

questions.explanation: Use 'any' with uncountable nouns in negative sentences.

questions.question: Which noun is countable?
questions.explanation: 'Apple' is countable: one apple, two apples, etc.

questions.question: Complete: I don't have _____ friends in this city.

content.sentence: I don't have _____ friends in this city.

questions.explanation: Use 'many' with countable nouns in negative sentences.

questions.question: Which is correct?

choices: There are a lot of apples.
There is a lot of apples.

questions.answer: There are a lot of apples.
questions.explanation: 'A lot of' can be used with countable nouns in positive sentences.

questions.question: Complete: Is there _____ milk in the fridge?
